attributes.alt: Book cover for Ducks Away! By Mem Fox and Judy Horacek. The cover art shows ducks swimming and splashing in water.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary
What does Mother Duck do when her ducklings fall into the water?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, with a focus on operations.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set; Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to five objects; Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” and “beside.
Initiate play, and join a group in play.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Have children tell how many ducklings are on and below a bridge, represented by Connecting Cubes.
Guide children to see that the total does not change when counting in different orders.
What can happen when we try something new?
What new book did you choose? Why did you choose that one?
Pretend you are a group of ducklings. What will you do when you topple into the water?
How many counters do you have? What happens if you take one away?
What are you drawing? Could you add a bridge in your picture?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of
? What does the rest of the word sound like? Let’s say the whole word together:
How can you build a bridge that will not fall over?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Ducks Away! By Mem Fox and Judy Horacek. The cover art shows ducks swimming and splashing in water.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to discuss how the characters show teamwork and to review equal groups.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set.
Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 objects into two equal sets.
Initiate play, and join a group in play.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Have children work in pairs to create equal groups of ducklings using Connecting Cubes.
Challenge children to describe their process and count to find the total for each group.
What can happen when we try something new?
How do the characters show teamwork in this book?
How are you using teamwork as you play?
Can you make two groups with the same amount?
Write a story about two ducks who work or play together.
Can you make a duck? What materials will you use?
What sounds do you hear at the beginning of
? What does the rest of the word sound like? Let’s say the whole word:
Make a pond. How many ducks are in it?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Ducks Away! By Mem Fox and Judy Horacek. The cover art shows ducks swimming and splashing in water.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to review spatial sense, engage children with an activity, and introduce vocabulary
Read interactively for deeper comprehension, focusing on spatial sense.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “up,” and “down”; Follow directions to move own body through space.
Initiate play, and join a group in play.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Ask children whether each Activity Card shows up or down.
Guide children to explain their reasoning.
Challenge children to describe other things  that go up or down.
What can happen when we try something new?
Where is the character on this page? How can you describe what’s around him or her?
How can you add more players to this game?
How does moving objects as you count them make it easier to tell how many there are?
Write about an animal that lives up in the air.
Draw something that floats up in the air.
What sound do you hear at the beginning of
? What does the rest of the word sound like? Let’s say the whole word:
Try making a slide. What can you push down your slide?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for I Like to Race. The chart shows a bike racer and says, I stretch. I get tips. I stay safe. I race!
Book cover for Ducks Away! By Mem Fox and Judy Horacek. The cover art shows ducks swimming and splashing in water.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about trying new things, engage children with an activity, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read closely to connect to this week’s concept question,
What can happen when we try something new?
Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to five objects; Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set; Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Initiate play, and join a group in play.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Have children move counters across a “finish line” and tell how many are on each side.
Guide children to see that the order in which “racers” cross the line does not affect the total count.
What can happen when we try something new?
Do you see any words that you can sound out?
Pretend to be racers stretching. Who can stretch the farthest?
Count these in a different order. Are there still the same amount?
Do you think it would be fun to race? Write about that.
Draw a group of people racing. How are they racing? Which racer is fastest?
What sounds do you hear at the beginning of
? What does the rest of the word sound like? Let’s say the whole word:
Work with a partner to build two racers. Which do you think would be faster?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Ducks Away! by Mem Fox, illustrated by Judy Horocek. Text copyright © 2016 by Mem Fox. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Judy Horocek. Published by Scholastic Inc.

attributes.alt: Book cover for Ducks Away! By Mem Fox and Judy Horacek. The cover art shows ducks swimming and splashing in water.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to engage children in an activity in which they try something new and with counting.
Start Story Time by revisiting the book
What new things do the ducks try?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on counting.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set; Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Count forward or backward from a given number up to 5 to solve a problem; Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to five objects.
Use position words such as “above,” “up,” and “down”; Follow directions to move a body through space.
Initiate play, and join a group in play.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Write a story about someone who tries something new.
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What can happen when we try something new?
What kind of book would you like to read next?
Find something you have never played with before. Try it out!
Create a bridge using Pattern Blocks. How many did you use? Can you count them in this order?
Write about something you have never done that you would like to try doing.
Create a food no one has ever seen before. Would you try it? What does it taste like?
Use letters to make the word
. How many letters did you use?
Which block is the tallest? Which block is the shortest?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Ducks Away! by Mem Fox, illustrated by Judy Horocek. Text copyright © 2016 by Mem Fox. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Judy Horocek. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Use concrete models or share a verbal word problem for adding up to five objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting zero to five objects from a set.
Blend onset and rime to form a familiar one-syllable word.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 items into equal groups.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Blend onset and rime to form a familiar one-syllable word.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Blend onset and rime to form a familiar one-syllable word.
Use concrete objects, create pictorial models, and share a verbal word problem for adding up to five objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting zero to five objects from a set.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play.
Blend onset and rime to form a familiar one-syllable word.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Use concrete objects, create pictorial models, and share a verbal word problem for adding up to five objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting zero to five objects from a set.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
